channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jo Cox, Member of British Parliament, Is Killed in Attack
item.media:description: A vigil in Parliament Square in London for Jo Cox, the member of Parliament who was killed in northern England on Thursday.
item.description: Ms. Cox, a Labour lawmaker representing Batley and Spen in northern England, died after an attack at a library in her district.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and PAULINE BOCK

item.title: European? British? These ‘Brexit’ Voters Identify as English
item.media:description: Residents of the Castle Point borough of Essex in England celebrated the queen’s 90th birthday this month. Castle Point is the most ethnically English part of the United Kingdom, with nearly 80 percent describing themselves as purely English, while 95 percent are white.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: In the debate over whether Britain should leave the European Union, a fierce sense of English identity could prove critical to the outcome.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Prime Minister of Croatia Is Ousted by the Party That Backed Him
item.description: The move against Prime Minister Tihomir Oreskovic brought down the Croatian government and ended a brief union between reformers and a nationalist right-wing party.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH OROVIC

item.title: Desperation Rising at Home, Africans Increasingly Turn to Risky Seas
item.media:description: Samba Thiam, 23, came to Dakar, Senegal, from his village nearly 400 miles away to look for work. He and more than a dozen other men now live in a concrete house in a development created in the 1970s to shelter the poor.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: More than 1,300 migrants have died trying to cross the Mediterranean in boats from North Africa in the last few weeks alone.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Judge in Kenya Upholds Use of Anal Exams for Men Suspected of Being Gay
item.media:description: Kenyan supporters of gay rights protesting proposed anti-gay legislation in Uganda in 2014.
item.description: The court denied a petition to overturn the use of mandatory anal exams in Kenya, where homosexual sex can lead to an arrest.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Lethal Government Force Brings Ethiopian Region to Fearful Standstill
item.media:description: People mourned the death of Dinka Chala, who was killed by Ethiopian security forces, in December in the Oromia region. He was accused of protesting, but his family said he was not involved.
item.description: Since protests erupted in the Oromia region seven months ago, more than 400 people, almost all civilians, have died, according to a Human Rights Watch report.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Hong Kong Bookseller Says He Was Detained by China
item.description: Lam Wing-kee, whose bookstore sold gossipy books about China’s leadership, says he was detained at the border by captors who wanted customers’ details.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Davao City Journal: ‘No Smoking, No Crime’: Welcome to the Philippine Leader’s Town
item.media:description: Children on a beach in Davao City, the Philippines, across from the resort island of Samal, where four people were kidnapped by Islamic rebels in September.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: President-elect Rodrigo Duterte’s strict policies may be a tough sell in much of the country. But in Davao City, where he was mayor, residents say they feel safe.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: To Secure Loans, Chinese Women Supply Perilous Collateral: Nude Photos
item.description: Women are sending photos of themselves to peer-to-peer lenders, who then sometimes blackmail them when they cannot pay high interest rates, Chinese state media reported.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Dozens of U.S. Diplomats, in Memo, Urge Strikes Against Syria’s Assad
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria delivering a speech to the parliament in Damascus last week.
item.description: The internal cable, sharply critical of Obama administration policy, says military action is necessary to stop violations of a cease-fire in the country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Fighting ISIS With an Algorithm, Physicists Try to Predict Attacks
item.media:description: An explosion in Kobani, Syria, during fighting between Kurdish and Islamic State fighters in October 2014. Researchers found a spike in the formation of small online groups connected to the Islamic State before the attack began in September of that year.
item.description: A new mathematical model aims to track the activity of Islamic State sympathizers online and determine when groups will turn from talk to action.
item.dc:creator: PAM BELLUCK
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Palestinian Killed by Israeli Soldier Posed No Danger, Commander Testifies
item.media:description: The body of Abdel Fattah al-Sharif after he was killed by an Israeli soldier in the West Bank city of Hebron in March.
item.description: The commander said the Palestinian, who had already been shot and wounded after stabbing another soldier, was no longer a threat when Sgt. Elor Azaria shot him in the head.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: Not Just a U.S. Problem: Black Lives Matter Here, Too, Canadians Say
item.media:description: Black Lives Matter Toronto activists at a protest in April outside the Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada office in Toronto.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: A growing protest movement in Toronto, fueled by several police shootings of black men, has laid bare the frustrations of black residents.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: In Race for Mayor of Rome, a Prize and a New Face for the Five Star Movement
item.media:description: Virginia Raggi, a lawyer and municipal councilor in Rome. She appears poised to become Rome’s mayor in a runoff election on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Born as a voice of anti-establishment protest in Italy, the movement is poised to win the city’s mayoral runoff on Sunday behind Virginia Raggi, a relative newcomer.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: France Arrests More Than 300 in Euro Soccer Tournament’s First Week
item.media:description: A man was arrested last week as soccer fans clashed in Marseille, France.
item.description: Fan violence has marred the start of the Euro 2016 tournament and heightened security concerns in a country already under high alert.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Shifting Attention to Mediterranean, NATO Fights Internal Dissent
item.media:description: British paratroopers jumped from a C-130 Hercules plane during an alliance training exercise near Torun, Poland, this month.
item.description: Beyond confronting Russia in the east, the alliance is facing an array of challenges on its southern flank, including terrorism and uncontrolled migration.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Christo’s Newest Project: Walking on Water
item.media:description: A new installation by the artist Christo, “The Floating Piers,” consists of temporary bridges spanning Italy’s Lake Iseo.
item.description: For 16 days, “The Floating Piers,” a saffron-colored walkway, will connect two small islands in a lake in Northern Italy to the mainland.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: As Russian Hackers Probe, NATO Has No Clear Cyberwar Strategy
item.media:description: The Dutch warship Johan De Witt during NATO exercises off southern Finland this month. The maneuvers included an amphibious landing, the first by alliance forces in Finnish territory.
item.description: When it comes to deterring the low-level attacks that flow through European computer networks every week, NATO commanders do not seem prepared to take aggressive countermeasures.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Judge Denies Reza Zarrab’s Bail Request for Self-Financed House Arrest
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab, a gold trader facing trial in New York, in December 2013. Mr. Zarrab had offered to pay for his own detention while awaiting trial.
item.description: Mr. Zarrab, a gold trader from Turkey, had asked to be allowed to live in an apartment under 24-hour armed guard and GPS monitoring, all at his own expense.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: EgyptAir 804’s ‘Black Box’ Recovered in Mediterranean
item.description: The cockpit voice recorder from a flight that crashed as it flew from Paris to Cairo last month was damaged, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF and NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Letter From America: Donald Trump May Be Republican, but He’s No Fiscal Hawk
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump has made cultural conservatism, not fiscal restraint, the leading edge of his campaign from the beginning.
item.description: The effects that Donald J. Trump’s spending and tax-cut pledges would have on the deficit confound G.O.P. veterans.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HARWOOD

item.title: ISIS Committed Genocide Against Yazidis in Syria and Iraq, U.N. Panel Says
item.media:description: Yazidis fleeing Sinjar, Iraq, in 2014 after forces loyal to the Islamic State took the town. Kurdish and Yazidi fighters retook it last fall.
item.description: A commission of inquiry found evidence of mass killings of members of the religious minority.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: China Is Said to Rescind Invitation to Taiwan Children’s Choir
item.media:description: The Puzangalan Choir with the new president of Taiwan, Tsai Ing-wen, left, and vice president, Chen Chien-jen, at their inauguration in Taipei on May 20.
item.description: Organizers of an event in Guangdong Province canceled the invitation to the Puzangalan Choir after a performance at the presidential inauguration in Taiwan in May.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Red Tape on Spanish Visa Leaves Syrian Girl’s Surgery in Limbo
item.description: The girl, not yet a year old, is stranded with her family in Jordan as lawyers try to clear the way for her to receive an urgent and complex operation.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Detainees Describe C.I.A. Torture in Declassified Transcripts
item.media:description: A military base in Stare Kiejkuty, Poland, that the C.I.A. once used to detain and question terrorism suspects.
item.description: The government disclosed the transcripts, from military hearings of former C.I.A. prisoners, in response to a lawsuit by the American Civil Liberties Union.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Iran Accuses Thomson Reuters Charity Official of Sedition
item.media:description: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe in an undated photo. She has been detained by Iran since April 3.
item.media:credit: Free Nazanin Campaign, via Associated Press
item.description: The charge was the first explanation for the arrest in April of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a British-Iranian program coordinator for the Thomson Reuters Foundation.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Sinosphere: Expiration Date on China’s Promises Stokes Unease in Hong Kong Housing
item.media:description: A playground on the grounds of an apartment complex in Hong Kong. With housing prices soaring, many in the city struggle even to afford a long-term mortgage.
item.media:credit: Dale De La Rey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Most banks have yet to formulate mortgage policies beyond 2047, when an agreement guaranteeing the city a high degree of autonomy runs out.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Polio Strain Found in Hyderabad, India, Prompts Vaccination Drive
item.media:description: A man in Hyderabad, India, previously infected with polio traveled the city’s streets on Wednesday. The metropolitan area of 7.7 million people was placed on high alert by the Indian health authorities after a strain of polio was found in sewage water.
item.description: The health authorities in the southern state of Telangana said that no one had been infected, but they announced that they would try to vaccinate 300,000 children.
item.dc:creator: KAUSHIK SWAMINATHAN

item.title: Employee of Panama Papers Law Firm, Mossack Fonseca, Is Arrested in Switzerland
item.media:description: The building that houses the Mossack Fonseca law firm offices in Panama City.
item.description: The man was arrested after the firm filed a complaint, but it was not clear if the arrest was connected to the leaked documents that have led to investigations of globally prominent figures.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ERIC LIPTON

item.title: EgyptAir Flight 804 Wreckage Reported in Mediterranean
item.description: A search vessel in the Mediterranean found “several main locations of the wreckage” of Flight 804, the Egyptian government said.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Prince William Appears on the Cover of Attitude, a Gay Magazine
item.media:description: Prince William on the cover of Attitude magazine’s July issue.
item.description: The Duke of Cambridge’s cover photo shows a brand of activism that is reminiscent of his mother, Diana, Princess of Wales.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: A ‘Brexit’ Battle on the Thames Between Nigel Farage and Bob Geldof
item.media:description: A flotilla of fishing vessels campaigning to leave the European Union sailed up the Thames in London on Wednesday.
item.description: The question of whether Britain should remain in the European Union devolved into a naval confrontation in London on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: France Eases Rules for Police to Carry Guns While Off Duty
item.media:description: Soldiers on patrol in the northern French city of Lille on Wednesday.
item.description: The move came in response to an attack on Monday in which an Islamic State operative fatally stabbed a police officer and his companion at their home.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: India Sentences Man-Eating Lion to Life — in the Zoo
item.media:description: An Asiatic lion at the Gir sanctuary in the state of Gujarat, India. It is rare for lions to attack humans, but in the first six months of this year, there have been six killings in the area around the Gir Forest, which is home to India’s only population of wild lions.
item.description: Lion attacks on humans are rare, but in the first six months of this year there have been six killings in the western state of Gujarat.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Removes His Artificial Legs at Sentencing Hearing
item.description: Mr. Pistorius’s lawyers were trying to highlight the sense of vulnerability they say he felt when, acting out of fear and confusion, he fatally shot his girlfriend.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Wife and Son of China’s Ex-Security Chief Sentenced for Taking Bribes
item.media:description: Zhou Yongkang in 2012. He is currently serving life in prison for corruption and leaking state secrets.
item.description: Jia Xiaoye, whose husband, Zhou Yongkang, was until 2012 one of China’s most powerful officials, received a nine-year term. His son by a previous marriage, Zhou Bin, received 18 years.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Amman Journal: Finding Refuge in Jordan, and Adding to Its Cultural Mix
item.media:description: Omar Awad, a marble artist from Damascus, Syria, decamped to Amman, Jordan, four years ago to escape the civil war at home. Instead of designing the marble accents for mansions back home, he now arranges treats in a sweet shop in Amman.
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.description: Jordan has absorbed successive waves of people fleeing war and chaos. Some Jordanians blame the newcomers for unwanted changes; others say they have made Amman better.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Indonesian Doctors’ Group Rejects Decree on Chemical Castration
item.media:description: Seven teenagers being sentenced in Bengkulu Province in Indonesia last month for the brutal gang rape and murder of a 14-year-old girl. The teenagers each received 10 years in prison.
item.description: The decree, by President Joko Widodo, is meant to punish convicted child molesters, but the national medical association says it prefers longer prison sentences.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Obama and Dalai Lama Meet Over China’s Objection
item.media:description: The Dalai Lama after giving a public talk at Bender Arena at American University in Washington on Monday.
item.description: A Chinese official warned that a meeting between the American president and the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader would “undermine mutual trust and cooperation” between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Worries Flare Over Yang Maodong, Jailed Chinese Dissident on Hunger Strike
item.media:description: Yang Maodong, better known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, at a detention center in Guangzhou, China, in 2014.
item.description: For more than a month, Mr. Yang has resisted eating to protest his conditions in prison and to demand sweeping political change, his family said.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Australian Businessman, Sentenced in China, Gets Early Release Back Home
item.media:description: Matthew Ng had been sentenced by a Chinese court in 2011 to more than 12 years in prison on bribery and fraud charges.
item.description: Matthew Ng, convicted of bribery and fraud charges, had been returned to Sydney under a prisoner exchange treaty.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Sinosphere: How the Cultural Revolution Sowed the Seeds of Dissent in China
item.media:description: Red Guards waving copies of Mao Zedong’s “Little Red Book” as they paraded through Beijing in late 1966.
item.description: The sociologist Guobin Yang explains how the turmoil of those years paved the way for the political debates and artistic experiments that followed Mao Zedong’s death.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Tokyo Governor, Yoichi Masuzoe, Resigns Over Spending Scandal
item.description: Mr. Masuzoe, who will step down on Tuesday, is the second governor of the city to quit over a financial scandal in two and a half years.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Unbuttoned: British Fashion Takes a Stand Against Brexit
item.media:description: Sid Bryan, center left, and Cozette McCreery, center right, the designers for Sibling, wore shirts reading “In” to show their opposition to Brexit after their show in London.
item.description: The British fashion industry is finally waking up to the potentially damaging implications of Britain’s departure from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN

item.title: Leaving Past Behind, Northern Ireland Unified Behind Its Team
item.media:description: Northern Ireland fans applauded their team after Sunday’s loss in the European Championships.
item.description: A boy who watched the biggest soccer match in his country’s history in 1982 is now the coach. He hopes to replicate the team’s success in the European Championships.
item.dc:creator: JAMES MONTAGUE

item.title: What in the World: Rise at 11? China’s Single Time Zone Means Keeping Odd Hours
item.description: Some days, the sun doesn’t come up until 10 a.m. in Urumqi, where clocks are set to Beijing time despite being 2,000 miles to the west.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: The Deeper Meaning of Mexico’s Giant Speed Bumps
item.media:description: A well-worn tope in Mexico City, scarred by the undercarriages of countless cars.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: Suspension-killing wonders called topes, which crop up on highways and back streets alike, are a means of enforcing speed control and civility, and cannot be avoided.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: What in the World: Australia’s Answer to Invasive Carp: Unprotected Group Sex (For the Fish)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; photograph by Thinglass/Shutterstock
item.description: European carp are muddying rivers and crowding out native fish Down Under. So scientists hope to control their numbers using a strain of herpes.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: The Interpreter: When a Phrase Takes On New Meaning: ‘Radical Islam,’ Explained
item.media:description: President Obama, who met on Tuesday with the National Security Council, says the focus on the “radical Islam” phrase is “a political distraction.”
item.description: A dispute between President Obama and Donald Trump in the aftermath of the Orlando massacre can be traced to the rise of the Islamic State, scholars say.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: The Interpreter: Control and Fear: What Mass Killings and Domestic Violence Have in Common
item.media:description: Sitora Yusufiy, the ex-wife of the gunman in the nightclub massacre in Orlando, Fla., and her fiancé, Marcio Dias, at their home outside Boulder, Colo., on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Autumn Parry/Daily Camera, via Associated Press
item.description: Research by social scientists reveals striking parallels between what drives the two violent phenomena.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Mr. Modi, Don't Patent Cow Urine
item.description: India’s innovative patent system has brought cheap generic drugs to millions. Now it’s under threat — because the Hindu right is obsessed with cows.
item.dc:creator: ACHAL PRABHALA and SUDHIR KRISHNASWAMY

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Brexit Would Be a Colossal Blunder
item.description: A British vote to leave would be a colossal risk to no good end.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Eastern Europe Is Both Dreading Brexit and Ready for It
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote, memories of the communist collapse color Eastern Europeans’ expectations.
item.dc:creator: IVAN KRASTEV

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
